s.text: Postal Service First-Class/Priority Rates were applied to inbound mail, the Commission tried to identify the corresponding rates for the FPAs.
Postal Service First-Class/Priority Rates were applied to inbound mail, the Commission tried to identify the corresponding rates for the FPAs.
Thus any inbound mail piece would pay the First-Class rate, or the Priority Mail rate for items weighing more than 13 ounces.
It seems likely that U.S. and foreign mailers would prepare AO mail so that it would qualify for lower domestic rates applicable to printed matter and/or lower priority delivery.
This result is valid to the extent that the assumptions concerning the weight profile of the mail, and the applicability of First-Class rates to such mail, are valid.

Postal Service wanted to recover the $59 million in lost contribution, it could increase the rates on outbound LC/AO mail, excluding outbound rates to Canada, by 7.5 percent.
Postal Service and FPAs were to pay each other terminal dues applying full First Class mail rates to all LC and AO mail exchanged, the U.S.

The monies generated by the surcharge flow into a common pool to be parceled out to DCs by the UPU for quality of service improvements.
Our use of REIMS II data as a proxy for this distribution appears plausible, but no more.
Hence, it appears likely that the proportion of LC to AO mail is less for inbound mail than for outbound.

In the absence of data showing the weight distribution of inbound mail, the Commission employed, as a proxy distribution, data developed by European postal administrations in the course of preparing a new terminal dues system.

In the absence of data showing the weight distribution of inbound mail, the Commission employed, as a proxy distribution, data developed by European postal administrations in the course of preparing a new terminal dues system.
The Commission was not able to obtain any data on developing countries.
